comments.commentBody: I think it had more to do with the democrats willing to work together than with Romney. Democrats would not hold back their country's growth like the republicans have.

Mitts response in his first two minute comments were to inject himself into the Presidents anniversary. His ego is huge and he went downhill from there. How is the right wing going to take some of the promises he made? He created a tangled mess for himself. Jim Leher should never be allowed to moderate a debate again. How is he going to repeal Obama care and then replace it with the same thing we have? Doesn't he understand Congress? Because he could get along with Dems in MA. doesn't mean he can work with US Congress.

You are ready to commit other peoples lives to battle fairly easily.  What is happening in Syria is a civil war between factions that have hated one another for centuries.  I do not want American lives wasted in someone else s civil war.  If you are so gungho, go over there and help the Kurds defend themselves from extinction at the hands of our nato brother, the Turks.

I realize this is a minority opinion (especially given that I'm off to the left of Kruschev on most matters) but this attack on a NATO ally is precisely the excuse we've needed to get rid of Assad once and for all. I wouldn't suggest that the U.S. act unilaterally nor am I implying that we send American troops into the fray.  On the other hand, there is every justification for establishing a no-fly zone in the northwest of Syria (to start with) and for providing arms to those rebel factions that are unaffiliated with al-Qaeda. Let's face facts: Assad is a butcher who learned his lessons in enlightened governance at the knee of his dear old dad. He's already receiving military assistance from the opportunists in Russia and China and from his fellow butchers in Tehran (without whom he'd be hanging under a lamp post in Damascus by now).  By providing the resistance with the same sort of help we'd bringing the two sides into some semblance of balance.True, there's be recriminations from Moscow and Beijing, but, really, who would care?  And it's certainly possible that Syria might convulse and possibly disintegrate if the insurgents manage to take over. If so, the situation would be no worse than the one that exists now. The loss of our ambassador notwithstanding, Libya has not collapsed following the demise of its dictator, and our own credibility has actually ascended.
I'm with you in box 53, JPG.  (I did know ROEG though.)  I have no idea who MR. MIYAGI is or was, and I don't know if that Jason guy is MRAZ or MR. AZ.

Had to work pretty hard to finally understand what was happening. The hyphens led to the missing SUNs. The missing MOONs showed up a bit later, as there was no warning.

Down in the SW there were criss-crossing (& pretty obscure) proper names, so I ended up not getting the letters in boxes 53 & 60.

8D: ¡ What a mangle of English & Spanish ! How about "Dos menos dos" as the clue for "cero."

So now I had to check my almanac to see if there's an actual eclipse in the offing. There is a penumbral (weak) eclipse in about 7 weeks (AK & HI). I guess this puzzle was too good to be left sitting on the shelf for months.

-- jpgaskell

Those wishing to follow jj's link, lose the parentheses.  Click the link.  When the 404 error comes up edit the url to remove the trailing parenthesis.  I think the leading one is automatically discarded.

C-xC-c: is correct. The Catholic Church, a long time ago, gave up supporting the Creationist position. Each Catholic has the right to decide for themselves and the Church stays out of it.

When I was a kid, I do remember the priest, during a sermon, telling us that if we accept evolution, the Church's position was at the point evolution produced our species, God said something to the effect that "this is man."

Great Article! for Mergers and  Acquisition success, proven that helps the  deal fixing to ensure the successful integration of business operations, Just read a white paper on benefits of Financial and business http://bit.ly/PHnSmZ

The same applies regarding going back to work too, rational. He's expecting people to be *ir*rational, leaving possible earned money on the table and crashing their living standard voluntarily, deciding to be on the dole.

The illuminating difference being, that employers now don't have the latitude to hire back at that 0.5*xxx or usually much less because it's too close to the safety net. ( 'xxx' being the former compensation level.) Maybe that's his gripe, actually.

It's not a "marginal tax rate" that workers would even care about, Orwellian-like as it is that Mulligan has called it that as if it is a tax on work. It's really all about a compensation floor, that he'd rather see lowered, all the more latitude for the capital side.

Same issue goes regarding the minimum wage. If we're OK with leaving people near-destitute, there's a very low standard for what's better than that.

Maya @ Oct. 3, 2012 at 1:10 p.m.:

Let me first note that there was a typo in "The less stupid people see a problem as less trivial." I meant to say "The less stupid people see a problem as more trivial." I apologize for the unintended insult resulting from the lack of proof reading.

1. You have not answered my question: "what this global condition on the vector field you are talking about imposing."

2. "A continuous function on a compact set has an absolute minimum." was meant it to be part of the answer for my question. Let me put it succinctly this way: how would you pose a question? According to you, you would give out the answer (potential and existence of extrema) explicitly in the question, wouldn't you? By the way, have you ever had the chance teaching somebody? Is that your way of posing questions, by giving the answers first, Jeopardy (game show) style?

3. The infinite constant shift in potential was intended as a simple example, trivial or not, as gauge invariance mentioned in passing. So I mentioned something trivial. Are you implying I should not have? The puzzle problems are all "trivial". Are you saying I should quit from posting here?

(to be continued in reply)

Qassem Suleimani is a formidable foe. He is either smart or lucky (or both). There is the movie quote: Brains will only get you so far, and luck always runs out.

If he is smart, then he has long realized that there is more than one side to the story - which means that he could have doubts, which could be exploited. He could be turned by us. A good catch at any price.

If he is without doubt - a fanatic - his own unbalanced zeal could bring about his eventual destruction, either by us, or by his own coterie (or both, dare I say). Certainly, there are some ambitious types among his colleagues who are envious of his central status and power. Time will tell. A clandestine operative, of his calibre - who has his picture plastered in the NY Times front page - had better sleep with both eyes open, or not sleep at all.

Iran is a superpower only in bluster. They can't project power from their own coast into the Persian Gulf. Obama may be cool about another real war in the middle east, but even Romney isn't saying he has backed off. Look at the impact of the sanctions on Iran's "superpower" economy.
Assad was not elected in a free election.  He is not a legitimate leader.

Charles - you are quite correct when you write that "Israel could level Gaza in 24 hours". Even faster if it used its tactical battlefield nukes. However, it would then be guilty of having committed a holocaust.

So instead, Israel chooses to blockade Gaza, builds a 26 ft concrete wall around them and keeps the 1.7 million Palestinians living there in what amounts to a vast open air prison since 2007 with no end in sight. It's very own Warsaw ghetto; except on a much grander scale. All the while continuing to expropriate the Palestinians land through ever increasing settlements in violation of UN resolutions.

By the way, former Syrian dictator Hafez al-Assad whom you mention is estimated to have killed approximately 10,000 residents who had revolted in the city of Hama in 1982. The Israeli Defense Forces on the other hand are estimated to have killed at least 7,229 Palestinians since the First Intifada uprising began in December, 1987 to the present. Not much difference between the two regimes as far as the dead are concerned:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinian_casualties_of_war
Syria has already apologized.
If anyone thinks that Syria fired mortar shells into Turkey, there is a bridge I would like to sell you.  Remember the Tonkin Gulf Resolution.  I pray Nato and the US stay out of the Syrian conflict.

I believe you are wrong. Mitt Romney was cool and collected and articulated his positions quite well.  Obama was the one who looked exhausted and beaten, and rambled on with nothing new... and seemed content to let that old green energy (FAIL) subject slip by without comment.

S.C. Seaton from Michigan, I'm for Obama, but I don't think he won, not by a long shot. Romney did do some sweating, had a frozen smile and those deer-in-the-headlights eyes, but he was a passionate spokesman for a moderate Republican agenda, while still emphasizing enough enough far right positions to appeal to the base. Obama seemed too irritable, annoyed and cerebral, IMO. I was hoping Obama would hammer a haplessly Romney into the floor, but that didn't happen.

I am a staunch Democrat and supporter of President Obama, and believe that he is the statesman and his policies will steer the U.S. in the right direction, and that we have an exciting future under the President. I believe Mitt Romney is a venture capitalist who does not understand that America is not a company to be dismantled; that mindset combined with his social views would mean disaster for the U.S.

That said, I must hand the first debate to Mr. Romney, despite his false statements and deceit. He came on strong and the President was lackluster, to put it kindly. Whoever has been advising President Obama on his debating style should be reassigned. Anyone who knows anything about debating knows that body language and facial expressions count for more than the words that come out of the debaters mouths. No one really wants to hear in a debate about all the facts and figures and they certainly don't want to hear the same old stuff that's been said. They want to see confidence and assertiveness in confronting your opponent. They want style over substance, and that's what Mr. Romney delivered..

My hope is that President Obama watches the debate and learns from it. He has to come out swinging, metaphorically, in the next two debates. There is no reason that he cannot outperform an empty suit.

Let me add one more point about tonight's debate.

Romney talked about 23 million people unemployed, poverty has increased, people on food stamps have increased.

Yet President Obama didn't push back and say we were losing 800,000 jobs per month when he took office and now we've had 30 straight months of job growth creating 4.6 million private sector jobs.

Why didn't he trumpet that point tonight? He didn't even mention it.

I'm very disappointed in President Obama's debate performance tonight. He could have sealed the deal tonight. Instead, he might have let Romney back in the race - at least it buys Romney another week for people to take a second look.

The Obama campaign team better go to the videotape of tonight's debate and tighten up what he needs to get across. He wasn't sharp tonight. He better be much sharper and more prepared next week.

Sorry, typo

'We are NOT going to allow our campaign to be dictated by fact-checkers'.

paxgaea, Troy NY

It is easy to sound confident when you just make stuff up out of thin air, which Romney did.

***
Yes, it was much more difficult for Obama this time because he cannot "just make stuff up". There are millions of Americans willing to fact check him this time. Often, from firsthand experience.
Romney did lie and he has no conscience about it at all. That's one area he has practiced to a science.

Romney was able to literally "fact check" Obama right there on stage.

Tomorrow, the story will be that Romney "lied", the moderator was awful, etc. The truth is that Obama didn't have enough of a grasp of the figures to dispute Romney's claims tonight.
Yes, it was the same old nonanswers and outright lies only louder and with more gesticulating.
And the Obama team hopefully is producing ads that will do what Obama himself didn't last night; contrasting what Romney said last night with what he has said on those positions before.

@J M: I believe you have hit exactly what is going on. Romney does not experience any dissonance when he says things that are untrue or that are direct contradictions of his previous publicly-stated positions. That is precisely what made George W. Bush so able to deceive those who only look at the outward appearance to judge character and veracity. It is what made George W. Bush so dangerous.

1:05 pm

Maybe, after sleep on this debate overnight and have had a chance to splash some cold water on their faces come morning, it will finally dawn on them how enormous Mitt Romney's whoppers were during the debate. He just about reversed himself, for the millionth time, on every talking point, up to and including throwing out the much touted Ryan Plan with his denial that he is going to cut taxes on the rich.

Maybe it was wise of President Obama to let Pinocchio have his say and let the enormity and impossibility of it all sink into the collective consciousness.

Mitt was consistent: all talk and no substance.

Good Topic! For private equity firm, proven that helps the  deal fixing to ensure the successful integration of business operations, Just read a white paper on benefits of Financial and business http://bit.ly/PHnSmZ
Obama took more time.  CNN had that giant clock with each candidate's talking time displayed throughout the debate.
Congratulations to Just Me for getting to the crux of the matter with the evening's best paraprosdokian!

Cute. I actually had them tied on presentation but a big plus for the President on facts. However, the last two minute speech was definitely a plus for Mr. Romney, who faced directly into the camera and gave an obviously well-rehearsed and carefully written speech. President Obama seemed to be talking extemporaneously to Mr. Lehrer for most of his closing speech. Bad idea. Hopefully, that'll never happen again!
Yes, and what was all that arm-flailing about? He'd better watch it in the town hall debate at Hofstra; he could bloody the nose of someone in the front row.
Romney’s tough to debate. You never know which one will show-up.

If you understand with which people Romney has success, by and large it it people like the conservatives who are not interested in facts.
If you want to win the debate it is has nothing to do with genuine issues. It will be with that sharp blow to the shins that has your opponent screaming inside.
As some women kid when they go out for an afternoon of tennis: It isn't who won or lost. It's, But did I look good?
Ultimately it's a shallow situation. Just LOOK GOOD! LOOK TOUGH! LOOK SECURE! SOUND EFFECTIVE! Who cares about the facts?

Obama obviously was unprepared and so he was unable to do more than jab and ignore responses. Those unbelievable lies about Romney, he tried to use, were thrown back into his face. Romney is not a push-over, and Obama cannot use this as another Photo-Op. People have now seen past his carefully constructed persona. He is a Lawyer, and a Pied Piper for the nation's welfare beneficiaries. Other than that, he has little skills relating to fixing this government's fiduciary responsibility to it's peoples.

After 4 years, the problems he inherited and promised to fix, still remain.

Time to send in a new team. And a new coach.

@Fahey,

when you (and the rest of the NYT community who do so) say Romney "lied", are you referring to his desire to bring tax rates back to the exact same rate that we are currently (and have been) paying for the last 8-9yrs, which will be increased on December 31 unless Congress can come to some agreement to avert the "Fiscal Cliff"?

not a very strong argument and does disservice to those who actually have a legitimate point to make
Romney’s tough to debate. You never know which one will show-up.

Alex:

Romney threw Paul Ryan under the bus for voting against Simpson Bowles.

Romney just said he WASN'T giving the 1% a huge tax break. THAT should be the headline.

Romney said that RomneyCare here in Massachusetts is terrific, but ObamaCare (modeled after RomneyCare) is garbage.

When people look at the analysis of what was SAID, Romney might not look so hot. But I will give you that he was glib.

Obama did not have a mandate to fix the economy the way he wanted to. He had tenuous control over the House and lacked a filibuster-proof Senate. The Republicans did not accept his victory and decided that they wanted him to fail at fixing the economy, but not fail in such a way that it was evident they were responsible.

If rational people hire a guy and the guy fails, they look at who else is available, and they may want to give the guy another chance. They ask why the guy failed and who the other guy is. People who say "game over" are just begging to be ripped off.

Alex you said what is true but suprisingly many Americans seem to like the Barack Obama "do over" plan for fixing the economy.  The polls seem to show incompetence, poor records and general failure is not always a stopper to reelection.  We are not that smart, I talk to people every day who still think Barry is the next best thing since sliced bread.

"My plan..." - Barack Obama Translation: "My do-over plan for fixing the economy..."

Fact check...statistics...talking points are all irrelevant. Obama had a mandate to fix the economy. He failed that mandate. Game over.

Alex -- You win the HIT THE NAIL ON THE HEAD award...

Thank you.

That's the Clint Eastwood way to look at it. Despite the derision and condenscencion of my fellow Obama supporters, that old guy (he is four yeasr older than I!) was quite effective and Romney may have learned thing or two from Eastwodd's presentation at the 'convention'.

I don't think FDR solved the Great Depression in one term either but he was re-elected because he was willing to try a lot of things (including SS) Republicans still rail against.  Obamacare has not been fully implemented but Romney wants to start all over before the baby's out of the crib.  And with what...vouchers?  State control?  Just pass it on to some other gov't agency but don't call it the federal gov't.  The game ain't over yet.

"My plan..." - Barack Obama Translation: "My do-over plan for fixing the economy..."

Fact check...statistics...talking points are all irrelevant. Obama had a mandate to fix the economy. He failed that mandate. Game over.
